With refrigeration at her kiosk she would not have to carry the heavy dishes to work, and would be able to avoid the risk of running out of food on a busy day.

Maria V. belongs to a village bank called “Ayni” which is a quechua (native language) word that means “I help you now, you help me later”. So Maria has friends in her village bank like Benita Sierra. Maria and Benita are expecting together a total loan of US$ 900.

loans.use: To purchase a small refrigeration device

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Far from downtown Ayacucho, Peru, on an unpaved road frequented by goats, chickens, and the occasional car, lives Julia H. T.. No more than 5 feet tall, Julia has a warm smile and plenty of jokes to tell. She opens the small, nondescript metal door to her grocery store that she has owned for more than 12 years. She has always worked in this same storefront near her home, but the shop today is far from where she began.

Julia is a busy mother of 7 children. Her husband is often away, working in agriculture in the “chacra,” or the countryside. Julia started selling beverages, such as water and soda, to supplement her husband’s meager income. Over the past decade, however, she has expanded the products she offers bit by bit. After beverages, she moved on to household cleaning supplies and snacks. A few years later, she began selling spices and canned goods. Most recently, she has begun selling rice, sugar, and flour, which have turned out to be her most popular items. She also has a large basket of kumquats, which she grows and picks in her own garden. These small orange fruits are very popular with the neighborhood whenever they are in season.

Julia hopes to receive a loan of $500. She would like to use this money to purchase more inventory of all of her items, to prevent selling out. She would also like to start selling fresh milk, which she thinks there is a demand for. She would use part of the money to purchase a cold case and test the new product.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory of all of her items, and to purchase a cold case to start selling fresh milk.

loans.name: Edis

texts.es:
I have this small business selling clothes out of my home. I'm also a travel saleswoman, making stops at offices in town, which is where I find my best customers. Currently I need to purchase more jeans, shirts, pants and skirts to meet my clients' demands. This business really helps me and my husband with household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Tengo este pequeño negocio de venta de ropa en mi casa, tambien soy vendedora ambulante ya que voy y vistos oficinas en my pueblo. En las oficnas es donde tengo la mayoria de mis clientes los cules son muy buenos.Ahora nesecito comprar mas jeas, camisa, pantalones y faldas ya que tengo muchos pedidos de mis clientes. Este negocio es mi sustengo diario cuan el cual apoyo mucho ami esposo con los gastos de la familia.

loans.use: Purchase jeans, shirts, pants, skirts, etc.

loans.name: Noemi Marlene

texts.es:
My name is Noemi Cabrere. I have made my living selling tortillas for the past five years. I run this small business out of my home. I have good sales, since my neighbors buy their tortillas from me, as do people from other parts of town and some restaurants. Now I want to purchase more corn and lime and another fryer so I can make more tortillas. This business is my only source of income and how I help my family.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Mi nombre es Noemi C., me dedico a la venta de tortillas hace 5 años. este pequeño negocio lo tengo en mi casa. Tengo muy buenas ventas ya que mis vecinos me compran y tambien parte de la comunida y algunos restaurantes. Ahora quiero comprar mas maiz y cal y compar otro comal para poder a gregar a mi fogon y poder hacer mas tortillas ya que no doy avasto con el que tengo. Este engocio es la unica fuente de ingreso que tengo y a la ves ayudo a mi familia.

loans.use: Purchase salt, lime, corn and a fryer

loans.name: Elisa Marina

texts.es: My name is Elisa Marina O. and I make and sell chicken and meat tamales. I have had my business for six year and I have a good clientele since my products are purchased for parties, reunions and special get-togethers. My business generates enough income to support my family and my goal is to increase sales.

loans.use: Purchase chicken, cabbage, tomatoes, green chilies, etc.

loans.name: Francisca Orfilia

texts.es: Hello, my name is Francisca A. and I make and sell corn tortillas. I have had my business for 4 year and I my daughters help pack and distribute my product. I have loyal customers because my product is sold in different grocery stores and markets in our neighborhood. With the loan, I will be able to remodel the store and build another furnace.

loans.use: Purchase corn flour, lime, salt, water, firewood, matches and coal

loans.name: Paula

texts.es:
I have run this small convenience store for three years. Now I need to purchase more products in order to sell common goods like bananas, beans, rice, tortillas, churros and bread. This business helps me purchase medicines and afford electricity, water and the like. It is my only source of income. I would like it if you helped me be able to purchase these products, give my customers a better service and increase my sales.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Yo tengo este pequña pulperia hace 3 años, ahora nesecito comprar mas productos para poder vender mas como: platanos, frijoles, arroz, tortilla en bolsas, churros, confites y pan. Con ete negocio me puedo comprar yo mis medicinas ya tambien pagar gastos como electricidad, agua y otros. Este es el unico sustento que tengo. me gustaria que me ayudaran para poder comprar estos productos y asi dar un mejor servicio a mis clientes y tener mas ventas.

loans.use: Purchase churros, rice, beans, sugar, bread, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Continue to diversify her product line

loans.name: Vasiliy

texts.en:
Vasiliy is a taxi driver who provides transportation services throughout Ukraine. He is married with two grown sons. His business has been the only source of income for his family. Vasiliy understands his role as head and provider for his family and is ready to work 24/7 to provide for the needs of his loved ones. He has been faithfully working in this business for seven years. 

Currently, Vasiliy’s daily income is about $40-50. An economical diesel engine in his car helps him reduce his operating costs and add to his bottom line. The fifteen loans that Vasiliy has received from Nadiya Ukraine have helped to promote stability and growth in his business.  

Vasiliy is asking for a loan of $1,000 to help purchase a newer, more comfortable car for long distance trips around the Ukraine. Vasiliy decided to become self-employed when the auto company he had worked for went bankrupt. He understands the effort and commitment it takes to be a private entrepreneur, and is willing to work hard in his business to be able to support his family which is the first priority in his life.

loans.use: Purchase new vehicle

loans.name: Andrei

texts.en:
Andrei is married and has an 8-year-old son. He has always been interested in machinery and technologies. That is why he decided to start his own small repair business. Andrei owns a maintenance shop providing car repair services in the town of Ugriniv, Ivano-Frankivsk region.

Andrei has been in this business for five years. Flexibility, customer friendly service and deferred payment options are some of the reasons his business has been so popular in the community. “Nadiya Ukraine” lending services have promoted the growth and profitability of his venture. Andrei has received and promptly repaid three loans with no defaults. Currently, he makes about $2,000 of monthly net profit.

Andrei is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy 600 liters of motor oil for his maintenance operation. He is hoping that offering different types of refined oils, as well as a full range of other petroleum products, will increase his sales and allow him to provide better service for his customers and enhance their vehicles' performance. We believe Andrei’s focused approach to business and his diligent hard-work will help him repay this loan on time and expand his business as a result.

loans.use: Purchase oil for repair shop

loans.name: Terisa

texts.en:
Terisa is a 36 year old fisherwoman with three children. Apart from fishing, she also makes traditional Samoan necklaces. After selling her products, she makes $300 weekly, which helps provide for her family’s basic necessities and her children’s education. Terisa is happy to have SPBD assist her financially with her work especially as she is so fond of her work and the good money that it brings her family.

Terisa is requesting an $800 loan to buy paint, fishing nets, cement, timber, sand and an iron roof.

loans.use: To buy paint, fishing nets, cement, timber, sand and an iron roof.

loans.name: Aloema

texts.en:
Aloema tends to her vegetable garden everyday. It is a hobby that has now turned into a money making activity to earn extra cash to supplement her husband’s earnings. Now that her three children are in school, money is always needed not only for their lunches but also other fundraising activities in school. Aloema earns $200 profit a week from the sale of her vegetables to the local villagers as well as the customers she has when she takes her produce to market.

Aloema is requesting $800 to purchase fertilizer, fagavao, cement, timber, sand and an iron roof.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, fagavao,  cement, timber, sand and an iron roof.

payments.comment: SPBD is pleased to report that Aloema was able to repay her loan ahead of the repayment schedule.  She is now applying for her 4th loan through SPBD.  Since receiving her loan, she continued to grow her vegetable business and added taro and banana to her produce.  She also had another child.  Kiva Lenders, thank you for your support!

loans.name: Eirene

texts.en:
Eirene and her husband are hardworking people who do not want to rely on their families overseas to assist them financially so each of them specializes in areas of fishing and planting. After all their hard work in planting crops and catching fish,they sell their produce at the market.

The family earns $500 from the fish and root crops they sell, and they are happy with how things at home are improving. They are also really thankful for the SPBD's assistance, which they hope will continue. Eirence and her husband are now requesting a loan of $800 to help expand their fishing business.

loans.use: To buy a boat, gears, fishing net, cement, timber, sand and an iron roof.

loans.name: Seuga

texts.en:
Seuga owns a fruit and vegetable garden. She is always to be found tending her garden when her daily chores are finished. In the evening she goes around the village to sell her produce,earning about $40 daily. At the same time her brothers help her out in her big banana plantation, especially during the harvest process. These bananas are sold at the local market at affordable prices, which earns Seuga about $240. She uses her earnings to make her loan repayments, provide her family with food everyday and attend to other family and church obligations.

Seuga is requesting $800 to purchase cucumbers, fertilizer, cement, timber, sand and an iron roof for her fruit and vegetable garden.

loans.use: To purchase cucumbers, fertilizer, cement, timber, sand and an iron roof for her fruit and vegetable garden.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Children are really into sweets-and this is the motive behind Naomi’s ice-block stall. She knows that she can earn some money by making ice blocks everyday to sell in the school in her village. She also knows that apart from school children, other people will want to buy her ice-pops. A week's worth of sales earns her $100.

Naomi also works on a plantation and, being single, her siblings are always eager to help her out. She grows different varieties of root crops and takes them to the market where their sale earns her $200. All her hard work has paid off well for her and she is excited and hoping to ask for more financial assistance from SPBD. In the future she plans to expand her plantation and also her food stall. She is asking for a $1,200 loan to expand and buy more material for her current ice-block stall.

loans.use: To purchase plastic bags, cool aid, sugar, cement, timber, sand and an iron roof for her ice block stall.

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
An intimidating horD. of barking dogs greets strangers at the door to Julia’s home in Ayacucho, Peru. A hardworking mother of 12, Julia knows how to handle the pack, using harsh words and even sticks when the need be. Her sturdy build and serious features mask a gentle, mothering woman who is both business savvy and nurturing, depending on the circumstance.

Julia speaks only Quechua, the native language of the indigenous Andean people. Every week she travels 13 hours in a crowded truck into the rural zones of Peru. She then spends three days gathering cactus and other plant material to haul home in large burlap sacks. She then dries the moisture from the plants, to produce a natural pigment used to color fabric, yarn, and is even used for hair dye. Julia then sells this pigment to customers who travel 8 hours from Lima to make the purchase, which they know is of a reliable, high quality.

Julia hopes to receive a loan of $500, which she will use to purchase larger quantities of the raw material. She will also use part of the money to help her daughter, who has just started a small business drying animal hides for leather, which will be processed and sold for shoe production.

Julia belongs to a village bank called “Amauta Huamanga” where she friends in the same situation as hers, like Josefa Quispe, who is also a business woman who hopes to receive a US$ 700 loan. Both, Julia and Josefa are expecting together a total loan of US$ 1,200

loans.use: To purchase raw material

loans.name: Fale

texts.en:
Fale is married with 6 children and lives in the village of Malie. Her husband works their taro plantation and she helps with selling the taro. She sells 2-3 bags of taro once a week at Fugalei market, from which she earns $200-$250.

Fale said that “Before joining the program, [her] family depended only on remittances from overseas.” This changed when she joined South Pacific Business Development in 2004. She was able to access loans so she could pay for her children's school fees and a lot of other family expenses. She is requesting an $800 loan to buy fertilizer and weedkiller for the taro plantation.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and weedkiller for the plantation

loans.name: Fotu

texts.en: Fotu is a young married woman from Siumu, operating a banana plantation not far from her backyard. Her husband works the land in the plantation. She joined the South Pacific Business Development program in 2005 and is now on her fifth loan. She used to sell 15-20 bags of banana at Fugalei Market and she received $200-$300 a week from those sales. She is requesting a loan of $800 to buy more raw material for the plantation.

loans.use: To buy more raw material for the plantation

loans.name: Palagi

texts.en: Palagi is a mother of 4, residing in the village of Taufusi. She runs a flea market selling handicrafts at Fugalei Market. Her sales exceed fifty items daily and earn her about $150-$200. She uses her income to support her business and pay school fees for two of her children. She is requesting an $800 loan to buy more inventory for her business.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her business

loans.name: Yorleny

texts.es:
Business Description

Yorleny used to work doing domestic chores from her home. She has 1 year of experience on cosmetic sales. She was motivated to start her own business by her aunt and Yorleny was able to gather the capital toinvest in cosmetics. She has her own business thanks to her determination to save some money to start it. She works every day of the week from 8 a.m. until 6 p.m. Yorleny has a good clientele to whom she distributes her products.

Loan Investment

The loan will be use to buy cosmetics and other products that she sells like: perfumes and costume jewelry. Yorleny also plans to invest some of the money in clothes too since she has orders already.

Personal Information

Yorleny is 26 years old and has 3 children. Two of the children go to school. Her husband works as a bricklayer and helps with the expenses at home. Her small home is made out of reed and has only one room (her dining room and bedroom are together). Her wish is to provide security for her residence where her children can grow without fears.

Traslated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer.

Descripción del Negocio

Yorleny tiene experiencia de 1 año en su negocio. Ella se dedicaba a trabajar realizando quehaceres domésticos en casa. Por medio de una tía, se motiva a conseguir un capital para invertir en cosméticos. Gracias a sus ahorros tiene su negocio. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 8 a.m. hasta las 6 p.m. Tiene una buena cartera de clientes a los que le distribuye sus productos.

Uso del Préstamo

El crédito lo invertirá en compra de cosméticos como lo son: perfumes, bisutería, joyas. Además piensa invertir algo de prendas de vestir para la venta ya que tiene pedidos.

Información Personal

Yorleny tiene 26 años. Y 3 hijos de los cuales 2 estudian. Su esposo trabaja realizando trabajos de albañilería. Con lo que también ayuda con los gastos del hogar. Su casita es de caña y tiene un solo ambiente. Es decir comedor y dormitorio junto. Su deseo es poder darle seguridad a su domicilio donde sus hijos puedan crecer sin temores.

loans.use: To invest in cosmetics other products for her business.

loans.name: Víctor

texts.es:
Business Description

Victor has 30 years of experience in this business. He started by working with his brother when he was 18 years old. He learned the trade from him. Thanks to his savings and the knowledge he had, he decided to open his own shop. He started by buying tools and some machinery to make his products. Today, he works every day from 8 a.m. until 6 p.m. His son and his son-in-law work with him at the shop. They are also learning the trade from him

Loan Usage

The laon will be invested to buy raw materails like: wood strips, glues, and nails. That way Victor will be able to improve the service that he offers.

Personal Information

Victor is 59 years old. He has 6 children and only one, who is 11 years old, is still with him. Victor still provides for him and for his education. Their home is a mixed construction and he hopes that he can make some improvements to it in the future like dividing it into different rooms. Also to be able to change some of the zinc boards on his shop because during winter is very uncomfortable to work at his shop in a normal fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer.

Descripción del Negocio

Víctor tiene una experiencia de 30 años en el negocio. Se inicio trabajando junto a su hermano a la edad de 18 años. De donde el pudo aprender el oficio. Gracias a sus ahorros y el conocimiento que poseía decide montar su propio taller. Comprando maquinas para elaborar sus productos. Actualmente trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 8 a.m. hasta las 6 p.m. En su taller trabaja con su hijo y un yerno. Los que también están aprendiendo el oficio.

Uso del Préstamo

El crédito lo invertirá en compra de materia prima como lo es: tiras de madera, gomas, clavos. Para de esta manera mejorar el servicio que ofrece.

Información Personal

Víctor tiene 59 años. Tiene 6 hijos de los cuales solo un de 11 años esta con el . Dándole el estudio y alimentación. Su esposa se dedica a los quehaceres del hogar. Su casita es de construcción mixta. Espera a futuro poder realizarle algunas adecuaciones. Como lo son divisiones dentro del hogar. Y poder cambiar algunas planchas de zinc dentro de su taller. Ya que en época de invierno sufren las inclemencias del tiempo lo que no le deja trabajar con normalidad.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for his business like strips and glues.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Continue investing in products

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en:
Business Description

Carlos has 15 years of experience in shoe making and repair. He started out as an apprentice and learned the trade until he decided to start his own business. His savings allowed him to buy the necessary equipment. He works every day of the week from 8:00 AM until 6:30 PM in a rented space near his home.

Loan Use

He will use the loan proceeds to purchase supplies to manufacture sandals and to perform maintenance on his equipment. He also plans to purchase a display fixture for the shoes.

Personal Information

Carlos is 29 years old, is married and has two children. His wife is a homemaker and helps with the business as time allows. Their home is made of reeds. He hopes to be able to improve their home and provide a better life for his family as his business expands.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Descripción del Negocio

Carlos tiene una experiencia de 15 años en su actividad. Se inicio trabajando para un maestro de su sector. Con el que adquirió el conocimiento y decide poner su propio local. Sus ahorros le sirvieron para adquirir herramientas de trabajo. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 8:00 a.m. hasta las 6:30 p.m. Actualmente el local que posee es arrendado cerca de su domicilio.

Uso del Préstamo

El crédito lo invertirá en compra de materia prima para elaborar sandalias. Además de darle mantenimiento a sus herramientas de trabajo. Piensa comprarse una percha para poder exhibir sus productos.

Información Personal

Carlos es casado. Tiene 29 años y 2 hijos. Su esposa se dedica a los quehaceres del hogar. Y en sus ratos libres le ayuda con la atención del negocio. Su casita es de caña. Espera con la inversión realizada poder adecuar su domicilio . Dando de esta manera una mejor vida a su familia.

loans.use: To purchase supplies

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Business Description

Carmen began her business four years ago. She sells clothing for children such as pants, blouses, costume jewelry, matched sets and underclothes. She offers her clients personalized service and attention, every day from 9 until 6.

Loan Use

Carmen needs this loan to invest in more clothing and new styles, as well as buy fabrics to produce the matching outfits she makes for children. In this way she will be able to offer new variety to her clients.

Personal Information

Carmen is 20 years old and has one child in school. Her husband works outside the city as a crab fisherman. Carmen started her business with a small loan. She makes her sales travelling around to areas close to her small wooden house. She hopes to improve and grow her business, so that she can help improve her home and better help her parents as well.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

Descripción del Negocio

Carmen inicio su negocio hace 4 años. Los productos que vende son: Prendas de vestir para niños como pantalones, blusas, bisuteria,conjuntos e interiores. La atención de su clientela la realiza de manera personal todos los días desde las 9am-a -6pm.

Uso del Préstamo

Carmen necesita del préstamo para invertir en la compra de más y nuevos modelos de ropa .Así como también adquirir telas para elaborar conjuntos de vestir para niños. De esta manera ofrecer nueva variedad de productos a sus clientes.

Información Personal

Carmen tiene 20años. Tiene 1 hijo que está estudiando. Su esposo trabaja fuera de la ciudad en la recolección de cangrejos. Carmen inicio con un pequeño capital prestado .Sus ventas la realiza de manera ambulante recorriendo varios sectores cerca de su hogar. Su casa es de madera. Aspira mejorar y crecer junto con su negocio. Para de esta manera lograr brindar una mejor ayuda a su hogar y a sus padres.

loans.use: Buy more clothing for her business

loans.name: Jorge

texts.en:
Business Description

Don Jorge runs a small shop selling gifts and other products. He started this business with savings obtained from his computer business. He sells gifts, clothing and school supplies. He serves customers from 6:30 AM until 10:00 PM seven days a week from a shop located in his home.

Loan use

He will invest the proceeds of this loan in additional merchandise, mostly clothing, as this is in high demand by his customers. He currently does not have enough capital to invest in more inventory.

Personal Information

Jorge is married and has a four year old daughter who attends preschool. He lives in a modest cement home that his father-in-law partly deeded to him and his wife. Jorge's wife buys and sell clothing in a nearby market to help cover the family's expenses. They are a very close knit family and they work hard every day to give their daugher a better education and brighter future.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Descripción del Negocio

Don Jorge lleva 7 años dedicado a la ventas de regalos y otros productos. El empezó este negocio porque también realiza todo tipos de trabajos de computación y con un dinero que fue ahorrando de lo que ganaba el compro mercadería. El vende todo tipos de artículos para regalos, ropa y útiles escolares. El atiende su negocio desde las 6:30am hasta las 10:00pm todos los días. Su bazar esta ubicado en su propio domicilio.

Uso del Préstamo

El crédito lo invertirá en mas mercadería sobre todo ropa, porque esta mercadería tiene mucha demanda de parte de sus clientes y el no tiene suficiente capital para seguir invirtiendo.

Información Personal

Jorge es casado y tiene una niña de 3 años que ya esta en la escuelita, el vive en casa de su suegro quien le dio de herencia la mitad de la casa para que el viva con su hija. Su casa es de cemento de un piso y muy modesta. Su esposa se dedica a la compra y venta de ropa Jean, ella trabaja en un mercado cerca de su casa, para ayudar con los gastos del hogar. Ellos son una familia muy unida y desean cada día trabajar duro de tal forma que puedan superarse para ofrecerle un mejor estudio y futuro a su hija.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Kelvin

texts.en:
Business Description

Kelvin has two years of experience in this industry. He used to work delivering propane gas tanks and learned the business that way. Six months ago he decided to invest his savings in this business and acquired his own gas tanks. He currently runs a small shop from 6:30 AM to 11:00 PM; his shop is centrally located and he has many clients.

Loan Use

Kelvin needs this loan to invest in more gas tanks to meet the increased demand. This additional investment will allow him to greatly expand his business.

Personal Information

Kelvin is 20 years old, single and lives with his mother in his grandfather's house. Theirs is a humble and simple home. He's an only child and works very hard to help his mother, who is a single woman, get ahead. His mom has a job and also contributes to the family's expenses. They hope that with Kelvin's hard work and his growing business they will be able to make improvements to their home.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Descripción del Negocio

Kelvin lleva 2 años de experiencia en esta actividad, el trabajaba como repartidor de gas y fue aprendiendo el negocio y hace 6 meses decidió invertir un poco de dinero que había ganado y compro cilindros de gas. Actualmente trabaja en un local donde el mismo lo atiende desde las 6:30am hasta 23:00p.m. Su negocio esta ubicado en un lugar muy transitado donde él tiene bastantes clientes.

Uso del Préstamo

Kelvin desea comprar más cilindros de gas ya que los que él tiene no son suficientes para satisfacer la demanda que tiene de sus clientes. A mayor capital tendrá más oportunidad de crecer en su negocio.

Información Personal

Kelvin tiene 20 años de edad, es soltero y vive con su mamá en casa de su abuelo. Su casa es demasiado sencilla y humilde. El trabaja mucho para poder ayudar a su familia ya que su mamá es una mujer sola y el como único hijo quiere sacar adelante a su mamá. Su mamá también es un soporte para él con los gastos del hogar ya que tiene su trabajo que le permite generar ingresos para el hogar. Con el esfuerzo de Kelvin y mejorando su negocio aspiran arreglar su vivienda.

loans.use: To purchase additional propane gas tanks

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 27 years old and works as a mechanic in the industrial city in Kirkuk. He is single. He wants to borrow $1200 to develop his business and purchase a new testing machine for the garage. He wants to raise his assets and increase his income.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase new testing machine for the garage

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 34 years old and has small shop for cosmetics in Kirkuk. His wife works with him in the shop. He is applying to get $1200 to paint the shop and purchase new goods and do some advertising. He wants to develop this family business and enhance his children's life.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Paint the shop, purchase new goods, and so some advertising

loans.name: Lole

texts.en: Lole is a businesswoman of 36 years of age with four children. She started her business life  making handicrafts such as earrings, bags, and hats all in Samoan styles. She got very good money from her crafts, but she thought its still not enough for her commitments. That’s why she hopes to get a loan of $750 from SPBD  to  add additional supplies to her stock.  She’s thinking of getting a 2nd loan from SPBD to make it big and be a very good businesswoman in the future.

loans.use: Restock her shop

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en: Mrs O. is a woman of 65 years of age with 10 kids altogether. Although she has many children to raise  plus family commitments, she hasn't failed in taking up these duties. And it’s because of this particular business of ice-blocks where she started from her 1st loan of $750.She is now on her 5th loan of $1500 and it was used to repair the roof of her house and buy more ingredients for her ice-blocks. She has now also added her pancakes business which help the most in her repayments. She believes that without the help she got from the SPBD program through their loans that she could not raise her family and satisfy her family needs as well as her kid’s education. She is asking for a $1000  loan to improve her business.

loans.use: Business & Home Improvement

loans.name: Taikerise

texts.en: Ms Taikerise is married with four children. She just joined the SPBD program this year and hopes to get her 1st loan of $750 to start up her pancakes business. She says that it will a big improvement for her family's financial support and her children’s education. She hopes  to pay off this first loan early and to get another loan to buy things for her business and also to pay her children’s school fees. She likes the program's support and hopes to stay in it for a long time.

loans.use: Start up a pancake business

loans.name: Kerena

texts.en:
She is a young lady of 28 years of age with two kids. She didn’t finish school and ended up with no job. Mrs Kerena L. and her husband work very hard in their plantation in order to get some money. But they still need financial support in buying agricultural equipment and chemicals to make their garden grow well. That’s why she joined the SPBD program and applied for her 1st loan of $750ST to help out with the business. She said without help and support from South Pacific Business Development, she would not be able to make it.

At the moment she is able to sell more of her taro, bananas, and yams at the food market. She is very keen on the program because she believes that without the loan, she is unable to be a better businesswoman. She plans to get another loan in the future to extend her plantation and assist her family financially.

loans.use: Buy agricultural equipment and chemicals

loans.name: Telesia

texts.en: Ms Telesia is a young lady of 24 years of age with four kids. She didn’t have a good education and is a school dropout. She prefers  planting a vegetable garden that is a source of income to help out in raising her kids and taking care of her family needs. But apart from that, she still needs some financial help to buy the very needed supplies for her business such as fertilizer, weed killers and other vegetables seeds. She has  joined  the Good Samaritan program and hopes to get her 1st loan of $750. She is very much excited about the prospect of her business growing in the future.

loans.use: Buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Lemoe

texts.en: Lemoe A. Y. is a member of  the Samatau 3 center. She is thirty-four years of age and one of the successful businesswomen within the programme. Her business is fishing. Her father and brothers are the ones that actually do the fishing. The fishing can be done in the  day time but usually they prefer to do it at night. Lemoe is on her fifth loan and she is still doing the fishing business .Her income for a week is $300.00 tala and $1800.00 a week profit. She explained that fishing is a profitable business and also a very risky one. Lemoe dreamed of having a big boat so that her father and brother will fish more so that her business will become an industry where she and her family can export to the overseas market for a better price. Lemoe is asking for a loan of $1200  to buy fishing nets, hooks and other equipment.

loans.use: “Buy fishing nets, hooks and fishing equipments”

loans.name: Selina

texts.en: Selina is a widow, a lady of forrty five years of age. She has seven children and three are attending school. Her husband died last year but that hasn't stopped  Selina from doing her business. She has a son that works as a teacher and he is the only employed person in her family. She joined the programme last year and her business is chips. This chips are made from either taro or bananas. She works five days of the week and she sells one package of chips for one dollar each. She produces thirty to fifty bags of chips a day and therefore earned  $30-$50. The total sale for the week is $150 and Selina is willing to supply more in the future to assist her family financially. She is asking for a loan of $750 to by oil, two fryers and some knives.

loans.use: : “Buy oil, two fryers, and knives”

loans.name: Saitia

texts.en: Saitia is thirty seven years of age. She is a mother of nine children, including five that are in school. Her business is selling vegetables such as beans, cucumbers, tomatoes and pumpkins. Saitia’s husband is unemployed but he works on his plantation himself. changes. She sells the vegetables at the market when there is a lot, but usually she sells her product in the village. She earns $240 a week from vegetables and $198 from the plantation. Saitia’s vision is to expand her business by exporting her product overseas.She is requesting a loan to buy seeds and pesticides.

loans.use: :To buy vegetable seeds and pesticides.”

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her fruit-selling business

loans.name: Saoaiga

texts.en: Saoaiga M. is an active and honest member in South Pacific Business Development. She is on her sixth loan, and she is still running her shop successfully She also has a Fishing Business . These two businesses are both going well at this  time. The shop is open seven days a week. The sale she can get for the day is eight hundred to thousand a week. She also sells fish and usually gets about thousand a week. These are her two major source of income. The income she gets from fish assists her with her shop and also supports her family. She is a very successful businesswoman and she is looking for better ways of expanding  the shop  and export her fish to overseas market. She is requesting a loan of $750 to buy a freezer and enlarge her shop.

loans.use: Buy freezer and help to enlarge the shop”

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his grocery business

loans.name: Mai

texts.en: Mrs. Mai and her husband were born in 1969. They have a soft drink shop in their home. Their income is $10 per person/month. They must support their old mother and their daughter, wH. is a student at secondary school. Now they hope to receive a loan of $75 to supply their shop in order to make and save money for their family. They will repay the loan on a monthly basis.

loans.use: To supply her soft drink shop

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is married with two children.When he was 15 years old, his mother died. Two years later, his father died also. Since that time, as the eldest son, he has taken care of his two brothers and other family members. Life has been difficult, so he has worked hard to make ends meet. He has gained strength from my church and have given much time and energy to doing good work in his community on its behalf.
He wishes to buy his car and to stop renting other people’s cars. This will enable him to service his customers constantly without interruption of the car owners needing their car when he is on duty. It will allow him to save more money for my family and future since his profits will be his own. It will also bring more security to him as he won’t rely on the schedule of another to organize his financial and daily life. And it will give him the opportunity to assist the disabled with free transport without stress.
He hopes that with this loan he will be able to lift his family out of poverty and provide for their future. He also hopes that he will be able to do good work for the disabled and perhaps even some day develop a larger business to purchase a second car and rent it to another driver in need, such as he is now. If you are so good as to invest in his taxi business, your money will help not only me but many others around him.
George is pictured beside the car that  he hopes to purchase.

loans.use: to purchase a taxi-car and stop renting other people's cars

loans.name: Matlubahon

texts.en:
Matlubahon is an experienced specialist in sewing dresses. She has a high education as designer of women's garments. She worked at a school as teacher of handicrafts, but the salary of a teacher is not enough for supporting her family.

She rented a premises for her own workshop. Gradually she bought several sewing machines and employed two assistants. Her business consists of purchasing fabric and making dresses, then selling them in the market. The high quality of their dresses has attracted many clients to her workshop. Presently her workshop is one of the best-known workshops in the area.

Since 2006 she has been a client of Micro Invest. Her first loan was $100. Step by step she increased her loan limit to $1000.Today Matlubahon takes orders from individuals for sewing modern garments for them. She always tries to do her best to satisfy her clients. In future months, Matlubahon wants to sew national autumn dresses from velour fabric. She wants to buy several kind of such fabric and she is requesting $600 for this purpose.

loans.use: Purchase of fabric.

loans.name: Enid

texts.en: Enid is  married with three children. She resides in the Manyatta area in Kisumu-Kenya. She is a very positive and charming lady who has a great passion for the medical field. She wants to see development especially in her home area  and to help her people who she has seen having great difficulty to accessing good and proper medical centres. She hopes that  this loan will not only enable her to advance her level in pharmaceutical field but also to open a clinic where she will be able to help low income earners within her area of operation to access quality medical care.

loans.use: To open a small clinic to serve her vicinity

loans.name: Loan

texts.en: Mrs. Loan is 44 years old. She now lives with her 2 daughters and her son. Everyday she must work by repairing bicycles because she is divorced. Her daughters are students at high school. The main income from the small bicycle repair shop is $9 per person/month. She hopes to receive a loan of $75 to run her small shop so that she can continue to support her daughters at school. She will repay the loan on a monthly basis.

loans.use: To run a bicycle repair shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Bentah

texts.en:
Bentah is a married mother of four lovely children. She is a very innovative and hardworking lady. She loves to help around the community at her home area at Nyahera, Kisumu-Kenya. She belongs to a self-help women's group called 'Ongeza Maarifa,' which is a Swahili phrase meaning "increase your wisdom." They make a variety of products and are particularly involved in a project termed 'jiko kisasa' (earthen oven/cooker). This cooker was recently introduced, and due to the high demand, the group is targeting to buy a kiln with higher capacity than the one currently in use.

They also need to purchase a vehicle which would enable them a quicker and more efficient means of transporting their goods. Bentah also hopes that with the profit that she will make she will be able to ensure her children's future with a good education.

loans.use: To add more stock and purchase a group lorry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To restart her tailoring  business

loans.name: Priscah

texts.en:
Prisca is a married mother of six lovely children. She is an exuberant and jolly person always willing to help out for beneficial development. Her motherly nature tends to overwhelm all those around her, so infectious that you cannot even say no to her request.
She belongs to a self-help women's group in Kisumu, Kenya, called 'Ongeza Maarifa,'
 which is a  Swahili  phrase meaning "increase your wisdom." 
They make a variety of products and are particularly involved in a project
 termed 'jiko kisasa' (earthen oven/cooker). This cooker was recently introduced, 
and due to the high demand, the group is targeting to buy a kiln with higher capacity 
than the one currently in use.
They also need to purchase a vehicle which would enable them a
 quicker and more efficient means of transporting their goods. 
She hopes that not only does the profit gained by investing this loan for the business helps the group but she sees that life should only improve for her and her family after this.

loans.use: To stock up on materials as well as contribute to buying a group lorry

loans.name: Salimbek

texts.ru:
Salimbek inherited his profession, being a butcher, from his father, who inherited it from his father. Salimbek’s wife stays at home with their 2 small children. Salimbek’s parents also live with him. Once a year during apricot-drying season, his family dries apricots. The biggest portion of the family’s income comes from Salimbek’s butchery business. He purchases livestock at the local markets and then sells the meat in the village market. Salimbek has been doing business with “MicroInvest” for 6 months. Currently, he is planning to get a loan to expand his business.

Translated from Russian by Keith & Jamilya Leitich, Kiva Volunteers.

Салимбек унаследовал от отца его профессию – мясника, которая осталась отцу Салимбека от его отца. Жена Салимбека нигде не работает, у него 2 маленьких сына, и его родители живут вместе с ним. Раз в год в сезон сушки абрикосов его семья сушит абрикосы. Большая часть семейного дохода складывается от мясничества. Скот приобретает на местных базарах и реализует на базарах по кишлакам. В Микроинвест кредитуется в течении полгода. В данный момент собирается получить новый займ для расширения своей деятельности.

loans.use: to expand business

loans.name: Zuhra

texts.ru:
Муж Зухры находится на заработках в России вот уже несколько лет. Сама Зухра не имеет постоянной работы и сидит дома. Ей 34 года и она воспитывает 3 детей. Для пополнения семейного бюджета она занимается выращиванием домашнего скота дома. Это приносит солидный доход. Опыт работы Зухры в животноводстве 4 года. В Микроинвест она кредитуется недавно. На займ Микроинвест она приобрела одного бычка. На новый займ она собирается приобрести еще одного бычка.

For several years, Zukhra's husband has been in Russia working as a seasonal laborer. Zukhra has no permanent job and stays at home. She is a 34-years-old single mother of 3. To supplement her family budget, Zukhra raises cattle at home. The business brings a sizable income. Zukhra has 4 years of experience raising cattle. Recently, she joined MicroInvest lending program and purchased a young bull. With the new loan, Zukhra plans to buy another bull.

loans.use: For purchase one more gow

loans.name: Yaa Marie

texts.en: Yaa Marie K. is twenty years old with two children. Uneducated, her husband works as a self-employed electrician whose income depends on when he is contracted by local businessmen and households to do wiring in their houses and vehicles. To supplement her husband’s income, Yaa Marie runs a small shop selling utensils in the town of Magburaka, Sierra Leone. She does this in addition to selling vegetables during the harvest seasons. Her goal is to expand her current business and use the profit to better educate her children. She is therefore requesting a loan of $175.

loans.use: Yaa Marie would like to increase her stock of utensils and kitchenware for her small stand.

loans.name: Firuza

texts.ru:
Firuza is single and lives with her parents. Her business started 4 years ago, when she first started selling. At first she helped her mother and then started bringing and selling products herself. Firuza’s product selection includes rubber summer footwear, that she sells in the summer. In the winter she sells winter children’s clothing. Her 2 younger sisters help her. She reinvests a portion of her profits into her business and spends the rest on family expenditures. That is her contribution to the family budget.

Firuza has been a client of MicroInvest for a half year and her business has noticeably expanded. She plans on using her new loan to further expand her business.P.S in the photo you can see her sister,Firuza wants to rent one more place for her sister.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: to expand business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her clothes selling business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her clothes selling business

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Mrs. Feliciana C. D. G. is 51 years old, is married, and has 6 sons. The sons are of ages 32, 30, 23, 21, 20, and 14 and they all still live with her in the house. Even though she was not able to finish her studies and attain a high school diploma, she opened her own convenience store from her residence where she serves everybody in the neighborhood, selling goods of prime need. In the store, she works with her husband and the two youngest who go out and sell their goods to those who can’t go to their store. The eldest sons all work independently.

She confronted several hardships along the way since nobody wanted to hire her or give her any loans and so she started from nothing. She started out by cleaning clothes for families and did some fishing. In time, she was able to save enough money to start her convenience store. Now she can proudly say that she has been able to refurbish her entire residence as well as proviD. all her children with a stable living.

In addition to all these problems, her location next to the Paraguay River has brought about some hardships. Floods are sometimes common which not only make her work extra hard, but also limit the clientele that visit her on those days.

She requires the loan to be able to expand her business and make a salon for customers to sit down and eat, since she not only prepares food to go, but she also prepares lunches and dinners seven days a week. She also wants to buy more merchandise to proviD. a greater variety of goods for her demanding clientele.

loans.use: Construct a dining room to serve lunches and dinners

loans.name: Inocencia

texts.en:
Mrs. Inocencia González is 51 years old, lives in in a common-law marriage, and has 2 elder sons. She lives with her common-law husband as well as with 2 adopted children of ages 4 and 2. These are their nieces who they took into their house after they found out that their biological parents were beating them and keeping them unfed for days at a time. She now finds her herself a proud mother of 4 and works extra time just to make sure she can keep her nieces safe and sound.

Her spouse works as a security guard in the biggest bank of Paraguay. She has been working as a recycler for 5 years now. She mainly buys and sells materials made out of plastic, carbon, aluminum, and plastic.

She requests a loan to buy a horse and a carriage to facilitate her in her job. Her job depends a lot on means of transportation since rainy days make her job extremely hard and she is currently using a hand-drawn cart.

She is a part of a group of 15 enterprising women who call themselves Estrella del Sur who join together to help each other out.

loans.use: To buy a horse and a carriage

loans.name: Carolina

texts.es:
Carolina is 40 years old and a single mother of a 17-year-old son. She lives in her mother's house, which is located 3km from the center of the city of Encarnaicon. Carolina has worked for 12 years as a chef, earning a fixed salary, at a prominent hotel situated 200 meters from her residence. She was the only source of income in her family (her mother could not work due to her age and her son was a minor). However, Carolina was able to save, and 8 years ago, she opened a grocery store in her home. Her mother and her son help her. She sells all types of common products, like sugar, olive oil, milk products, beverages, and ready-made foods, which she prepares herself.

Her biggest concern has always been her son's education. Thankfully, her effort and dedication has helped her pay for the education of her son, who, in the coming year, will eventually attend the university. Since the cost of his studies will only continue to increase, Carolina hopes to advance her business so that she can obtain greater profits. For her to be able increase her sales, she must increase her stock. For this, she asks for a loan of 275 dollars to purchase products like sugar, olive oil, canned goods, and sweets in bulk.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Carolina tiene 40 años de edad, es madre soltera de un hijo varón de 17 años, vive en la casa de su madre, que se encuentra ubicado en un barrio distante, a 3 Km. del centro de la ciudad de Encarnación. Carolina trabaja hace ya 12 años en un hotel importante que se encuentra a 2 cuadras (200 mts) de su domicilio, como encargada de cocina, en donde posee un salario fijo, como ella era la única fuente de ingreso en la familia, (ya que su madre ya no podía trabajar por su avanzada edad y su hijo que era aún menor), Carolina pudo ahorrar y abrió hace 8 años, una despensa en su casa, donde la ayudan su madre y su hijo. En su despensa vende todo tipo de productos de primera necesidad como azúcar, aceite, productos lácteos, fideos, bebidas así como también comidas rápidas que ella misma elabora.

Su mayor preocupación siempre fue la educación de su hijo, gracias a su esfuerzo y dedicación ha logrado pagar los estudios de su hijo que el próximo año ya podrá cursar el probatorio para la Universidad. En vista de que los gastos del estudio de su hijo van aumentando, ella desea ir progresando y ampliando su negocio para obtener mayores ganancias; para ello tiene pensado aumentar sus ventas aumentando su stock de mercaderías, por lo que solicita un crédito de $ 275 que lo invertirá en la compra al por mayor de azúcar, aceite, productos enlatados y golosinas.

loans.use: To purchase product, like sugar, olive oil, canned goods, and sweets, in bulk

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya and her husband, Vladimir, have a small clothing sales business located at the city market in Novi Rosdil, Ukraine. A cheerful, responsible business owner, Nataliya has extensive experience in retail. She and her husband have owned their business for the past five years and prior to that she worked as an employee doing retail. Nataliya and Vladimir maintain an attractive display of both practical and fashionable clothing.

Nataliya has requested a loan of $800 that will enable them to purchase a good supply of men’s clothing inventory. Nataliya’s immediate goal is to sell enough so that she can purchase some items for her daughter before she starts school in September. Long term, she would love to eventually buy her own store facility and work on further improving the business.

loans.use: Purchase men's clothing inventory

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga has requested a loan to help open a second vending location for her clothing business. Divorced and the mother of a six-year-old son, she is a motivated, hard-working entrepreneur who has been building her business over the last year and a half. Olga’s plan is to open a second location where she would work and hire an employee to staff her current location. She recognizes the value of expanding and hopes to increase her total income.

Olga has benefited from the help of her friends who are vendors in the market and also from the financial services provided by Nadiya Ukraine. She has been a great loan client, having never been late with a payment. We are glad for another opportunity to assist with Olga’s business and excited to see how it continues to develop in the future.

loans.use: Purchase second vending location

loans.name: Amude

texts.en:
Amude O. is a young entrepreneur in Trou-Du-Nord, Haiti where she sells various goods, such as hygeneic products, food items, and clothing, in her community’s local market place. She and her husband, Lalase, have one young daughter, Wadlise (age 2), and Amude’s business has been crucial to helping sustain their growing family. With this first loan, she will expand the inventory of her store to better meet the needs of her customers.

Note: Amude is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this $750 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of this loan together. This group-lending methodology ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: To expand inventory of miscellaneous goods, such as hygeneic products, food items, and clothing

loans.name: Mannelle

texts.en:
This 37-year-old mother of three, Mannelle J. is the proud owner of a small grocery service in Trou-Du-Nord, Haiti. Mannelle’s business is a critical source of income for her three children, Michi (age 4), Nehemio (age 3), and Judelin (age 2), since it is a necessary supplement to her husband's, Antoine, work. With this first loan, she will expand the inventory of her store with essentials such as rice, coffee, and sugar to better meet the needs of her customers.

Note: Mannelle is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this $750 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of this loan together. This group-lending methodology ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: Expand the inventory of her store with essentials such as rice, coffee, and sugar.

loans.name: Maria Lucia

texts.es:
Maria Lucia is 22 years old and single. She manufactures blouses, skirts, and shawls, which she and her mother later embroider. They sell their product to the women of their community. She is a member of the Neblina1 Group, along with Ms Maria Hernandez Vasquez (blouse craftswoman). They ask for a loan to purchase silk and cloth to increase the production of her workshops.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

MARIA LUCIA , TIENE 22 AÑOS , SOLTERA , ELLA SE DEDICA A LA CONFECCION DE BLUSAS , FALDAS , CHALES ARTESANALES LAS CUALES POSTERIORMENTE BORDA JUNTO CON SU MAMA Y VENDE ENTRE LAS MUJERES DE SU COMUNIDAD . PERTENECE AL GRUPO NEBLINA 1 JUNTO CON DOÑA MARIA HERNANDEZ VASQUEZ ( ARTESANIA EN BLUSAS ) . AMBAS ESPERAN CON EL PRESTAMO INVERTIR EN HILOS DE SEDA Y GENEROS PARA AUMENTAR LA PRODUCCION DE SUS ARTESANIAS.

loans.use: To purchase material, like silk and cloth, to increase production

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria is 53 years old and married with 2 children. Her husband works as a fieldworker during the corn harvest. She produces napkins, shawls, and traditional Nahua skirts. She sells her products at the tourist market in the city of San Cristobal and also by request for those in the region. She is a member of the Neblina 1 Group. With the loan she hopes to purchase silk and cloth, and she also hopes to sell her products in the tourist areas of the region.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

MARIA , TIENE 53 AÑOS CASADA , TIENE 2 HIJOS , SU ESPOSOS TRABAJA COMO CAMPESINO EN LA COSECHA DEL MAIZ. ELLA SE DEDICA A CONFECCIONAR SERVILLETAS , CHALES Y FALDAS ( NAHUAS ) TIPICAS DE LA ZONA DONDE ELLA VIVE Y SUS PRODUCTOS LOS VENDE EN EL MERCADO TURISTICO DE LA CIUDAD DE SAN CRISTOBAL Y TAMBIEN A PEDIDO A PERSONAS DE LA REGION . PERTENECE AL GRUPO NEBLINA 1.CON EL PRESTAMO ESPERA COMPRAR MUCHO HILO DE SEDA Y GENERO Y ADEMAS LLEVAR SUS PRODUCTOS A VENDER A ZONAS MAS TURISTICAS DE LA REGION.

loans.use: To purchase material, like silk and cloth

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana is 45 years old and married with 8 children. Her husband is a fieldworker. She is an artisan and manufactures clothes characteristic of the region (napkins, scarves, blouses, shawls) and sells them at a booth located at the edge of the Tuxtla road, which is located in a zone heavily populated by tourists. She is a member of the Neblina 2 Group, along with Ms Petrona Mendez Gomez (a blouse and skirt craftswoman). With the loan, she hopes to invest in the purchase of more thread and cloth to increase her production, and essentially increase her profits.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

JUANA , TIENE 45 AÑOS , CASADA 8 HIJOS, SU ESPOSO ES CAMPESINO , ELLA ES ARTESANA Y CONFECCIONA ROPA TIPICA DE LA ZONA (SERVILLETAS, MANTELES, BLUSAS , CHALES ) Y LOS VENDE EN UNOS PUESTOS QUE ESTAN AL BORDE DE LA CARRETERA DE TUXTLA QUE ES UNA ZONA MUY TRANSITADA POR TURISTAS QUE VISITAN LA REGION. PERTENECE AL GRUPO NEBLINA 2 JUNTO CON DOÑA PETRONA MENDEZ GOMEZ ( SE DEDICA A LA ARTESANIA DE BLUSAS FALDAS ). CON EL PRESTAMO ESPERAN INVERTIR EN COMPRAR MAS HILOS Y GENEROS PARA AUMENTAR LA CANTIDAD DE PRENDAS A CONFECCIONAR Y ASI AUMENTAR SUS GANANCIAS

loans.use: To purchase material, like thread and cloth, to increase production

loans.name: Edilene

texts.en:
Edilene T. is the proud owner of a small grocery service in Trou Du Nord, Haiti where she sells food products like rice and sugar. Since her husband died several years ago, her business has been the only source of income for her and her son Angelitho T., age 22. With this first loan, she will expand the inventory of her store to better meet the needs of her customers.

Note: Edilene is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this $750 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of this loan together. This group-lending methodology ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: Expand her inventory of food products, such as rice and sugar.

loans.name: Rosalinda Margarita

texts.es:
Rosalinda is 21 years old and married with 2 children. She produces napkins and scarves, which she later hand-embroiders using designs characteristic to the region. She sells all her products in the artisan market of San Cristobal. She is a member of the Neblina2 Group, along with Ms Maria Lopez who produces artisanal clothing. Rosalinda hopes to invest her loan in the purchase of thread in bulk for her embroidery, and thus, drop her prices to obtain greater profits in her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

ROSALINDA , TIENE 21 AÑOS , CASADA 2 HIJOS ,. ELLA SE DEDICA A LA CONFECION DE SERVILLETAS Y MANTELES LOS CUALES DESPUES BORDA A MANO ALGUNAS Y OTRAS USANDO TELARES TIPICOS DE LA ZONA QUE ELLA MISMA DISEÑA , TODOS SUS PRODUCTOS LOS VENDE EN EL MERCADO DE LAS ARTESANIAS DE SAN CRISTOBAL. PERTENECE AL GRUPO NEBLINA 2 JUNTO CON DOÑA MARIA LOPEZ LOPEZ QUIEN CONFECCIONA ROPA ARTESANAL . AMBAS CON EL PRESTAMO ESPERAN INVERTIR COMPRANDO HILOS PARA SUS BORDADOS AL POR MAYOR Y ASI BAJAR SUS COSTOS PARA LOGRAR OBTENER MAS GANANCIAS CON LAS VENTAS.

loans.use: To purchase thread for embroidery

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca T. is a working mother of four children. Her husband is a tailor and they both work hard to provide an education for their children. Rebecca is very proud of her two girls who have just started in the local college. She proudly says, “I spend my income on my children’s education with the hope that they will take care of me when I am old”. Rebecca is forty-five years old and plans to diversify her business for more income and to save more profit for her children’s school requirements. She is requesting a second loan of $175.

loans.use: Rebecca would like to to diversify her business selling vegetables so she can continue to send her children to school.

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en: Isatu K. is twenty-eight years old and the mother of one child. She sells hot peppers in the town of Magburaka, Sierra Leone. Almost ninety-five percent of Sierra Leoneans put hot peppers into their cooking sauces and therefore hot peppers are a big business in the country. Isatu is only able to purchase two bags of the peppers a week and earns $20 as profit. If she could access a loan of $175, she would be able to purchase three more bags to increase her profit and reduce her time of traveling to purchase the items and have more time to run her business.

loans.use: Isatu would like to increase the inventory for her business selling hot peppers.

loans.name: Issa

texts.en: Issa K. is forty-five years old and married with seven children. He runs a spare parts and building material shop in the town of Magburaka, Sierra Leone. His previous loan from SMT helped him purchase some of the spare parts wholesale and he generated more profit. He would like a loan of $350 to expand his business and be able to purchase all his stock items in cash and wholesale.

loans.use: Issa would like to purchase additional inventory at wholesale prices for his building material shop.

loans.name: Marie

texts.en: Marie B. is married and the mother of four children. At forty-two years old, with ten years experience in business, Marie lacks capital to expand her grocery business. Her husband is a daily laborer whose income depends on when there is need for his service. This means that Marie’s income sustains the family’s livelihood. A loan of $175 will enable her to increase her income and expand her business.

loans.use: Marie would like to expand her long-standing grocery business.

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en: Isatu L. is fifty years old and the mother of six children. Although two of her children are now married, she works hard to see that the other four children go to school. Isatu’s husband works as a driver but his income cannot meet all the family expenses. Her business income supplements her husband’s salary and both are interested in seeing their children acquire a better education.  Marie is requesting a loan of $175 to expand her stock of utensils.

loans.use: Isatu would like to increase her business inventory for her utensil and kitchenware stand.

loans.name: Isata

texts.en: Isata K. is married with five children. Her husband sells cigarettes in the same town of Magburaka in Sierra Leone but his income is insufficient to provide for all the family needs. Isata’s income comes entirely from selling fish. Sometimes she is assisted by her husband who takes the fish by bicycle to village market days while Isata goes on foot to do the selling. She would like to expand her business and therefore is requesting a loan of $175.

loans.use: Isata would like to be able to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
A mother of three, Roseline P. manages a small grocery store out of her home in Trou-Du-Nord, Haiti. Through her business, she supports her husband’s income by providing essential products to her community, such as canned goods, sugar, eggs, and locally grown vegetables. With this first loan, she will expand her current inventory to better serve her neighbors.

Note: Roseline is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this $750 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of this loan together. This group-lending methodology ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: Expand her inventory with essential grocery items

loans.name: "tina" Cristina

texts.en: Cristina G. is the proud mother of 3 children. However, her children have left their home, leaving Cristina to take care of her grandchildren, her husband and herself. For this purpose she’s taking a loan. It is her second loan, and a larger loan than her last. She plans to buy cooking oil, rice, beans, some refreshments and the general components of the typical Dominican diet (typical foods are referred to as the “banner” of colors: white rice topped with red beans and the dark color of some kind of meat, which represents the blue on the Dominican flag) to stock her little “colmado” or general food store. She says she won't sell otherwise very lucrative alcoholic beverages as her religion doesn’t allow for it! This is only one example that illustrates that she’s a responsible person.

loans.use: Tina wants to restock her store.

location.town: Santa Rosa Community of Villas Lindas

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en: Aurelia G. had been cooking for 4 years before the demands of caring for her husband and children forced her to stop. Now, her husband has left her, and she has restarted (over a year ago) the business of cooking specialty fried dishes to order. During the day, in addition to cooking,  she has to take care of her 4 children (fifteen on down to four years old). However, because she lacks help, she must leave the children on their own, at home, when she travels to deliver her orders (every afternoon). Aurelia needs this loan to build her business and save enough money to move out of her current home. She was very upset when we went to her current house, because she doesn’t like to show how humble it is. It is difficult to get to her house; there is a ravine one must cross in order to get there, and the bridge that crosses it is not safe. (This writer, for one, was afraid to cross!) The polluted waters that run under the bridge attest to Aurelia’s desire to move, but she can’t afford anything else. In fact she lives here because she cannot sell it; no one wants to come close to the foul smelling river. The kids are now so used to it, that they can’t smell it any more. Nor do they seem to get sick, despite the multitude of mosquito and other ticks that bite them daily while they sleep.  When we told Aurelia she would be getting a loan, she wept out of joy in having her prayers answered!

loans.use: Buy raw materials to cook foodstuffs

location.town: Santa Rosa Community of Villas Lindas

loans.name: Justino

texts.es:
Justino has sold morocho, a typical Ecuadorian dish made with milk and corn, for eight years. He started this business with his own capital. Since a young age, he helped his mother in this same business. His wife also helps with the business. She sells phone cards for cellular phones. Justino works every day from 3pm to 10pm.

Justino asks for a loan to purchase more phone cards, especially since every day he collects more customers, increasing the demand. His capital is insufficient to satisfy all his customer's requests. The loan will help him increase his sales.

Justino is 34 years old and married to his wife Rosa with 2 children, one is a year old and the other is 3. His 3-year-old daughter is in a school near his home. Justino lives in the house of his mother, who gave him, as an inheritance, part of the upstairs of her home. Little by little he is building with cement the upstairs. Thankfully, his business allows him and his wife the ability to further the life of their children, giving them a better future.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Justino lleva 8 años dedicado en esta actividad de venta de morocho, una comida tipica de Ecuador hecha con maiz y leche. El empezó este negocio con un capital propio. Desde muy pequeño el ayudaba a su mamá que tenia la misma actividad y el luego se independizó. Su esposa también le ayuda con el negocio. El también esta vendiendo tarjetas para celulares. Justino trabaja todos los días desde las 15:00pm hasta las 10:00pm

Justino desea el crédito para comprar mas tarjetas de celulares, ya que él cada día ha captado mas clientes y esto a su vez ha hecho que la demanda aumente su capital no es suficiente para satisfacer esta solicitud de sus clientes, teniendo el crédito el podrá incrementar sus ventas.

Justino tiene 34 años de edad, es casado con Rosa tiene 2 hijos. De 1 y 3 años. Su niña de 3 años esta en una escuelita cerca de su casa. El vive en casa de su mamá que le dio como herencia la parte de arriba de su domicilio y él poco a poco la esta construyendo de cemento. Gracias al trabajo que realiza él junto a su esposa están luchando para poder sacar adelante a sus hijos y darle un mejor futuro.

loans.use: To purchase phone cards for sale as a secondary product

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes has been selling clothes for four years. Before opening her own business, she worked for her sister selling seafood. Her sister had always encouraged her to start her own business, and one day Mercedes decided to take her advice. She set out purchasing clothes that she would eventually sell in her own store. Mercedes made her initial purchases with some money she had saved, and with the generous help of her family and friends. Her store is open 1 p.m. to 6 p.m., thus allowing her to care for her house and family in the mornings.

Mercedes would like a second loan through the Mifex and Kiva lending operation so that she can continue to invest in her business. She will use the loan money to purchase clothes for the colder season and venture into new lines of clothing. She is confident these investments will continue to improve her business.

Mercedes is married and has five children. Thanks to her work she has been able to provide education to all of them. Her husband is a mechanic in a workshop in the capital. She hopes that in the future she will be able to repair her house and make it cement- a goal that will make all of her and her husband's struggles worthwhile.

loans.use: Invest in a new clothing business

loans.name: Maria Elizabeth

texts.es:
Maria Elizabeth is married and lives in the Apodaca area of Nuevo Leon. Twelve years ago she started selling cosmetics to help her husband with the household expenses and their children's education. They have recently acquired their own home because their previous rents reduced the family's income greatly. At a previous job, Maria started selling her products to colleagues at work. Little by little her customers and the number of products she marketed increased. Now, she only dedicates herself to her business, exhibiting her work at people's homes, which has helped her business grow rapidly.

At this time, Maria is asking for a loan of 925 dollars to purchase merchandise to help her meet her customer's demands and continue growing her business. She intends to pay off her loan in 6 months. You can help Maria improve her family's way of life. They sincerely appreciate your support.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Maria Elizabeth es casada y vive en la localidad de Apodaca en Nuevo León. Hace doce años ella empezó a vender cosméticos para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de su hogar y de la educación de sus hijos, ya que acababan de adquirir su propia casa y las hipotecas que pagaban reducían mucho el ingreso familiar. Anteriormente tenía un empleo y comenzó sus ventas entre sus compañeras de trabajo, poco a poco fue incrementando sus clientes y la cantidad de productos que comercializaba, ahora solo se dedica a su negocio y realiza demostraciones en casas de familiares, lo que le han ayudado a crecer rápidamente.

En estos momentos Maria está solicitando un préstamo de $ 925 dólares que destinará a la compra de mercancía para poder cubrir la demanda de sus clientes y continuar creciendo con su negocio, ella promete devolver esta cantidad en 6 meses. Tú pues ayudar a Maria a mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia, ellos agradecen sinceramente tu apoyo.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To make improvements to the facility where he raises pigs and to obtain a market stall for fruit sales

loans.name: Maria Guadalupe

texts.es:
Maria Guadalupe lives in Apodaca in the Mexican state of Nuevo León. She is married and her husband works for a local business, but his salary is insufficient to cover the family's basic needs. To obtain extra income, Maria started selling cosmetics 10 years ago. She has had to work very hard to make her business grow, but the desire to increase sales and improve her family's quality of life is constant motivation for her.

To meet the demands of her clients, Maria is requesting a loan of $925 to purchase supplies. She plans to repay it within six months. You can contribute to her business' development and the well being of Maria and her family. They are very grateful for your support.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

En la localidad de Apodaca, Nuevo León vive Maria Guadalupe, ella es casada y su esposo trabaja como empleado en una empresa pero el salario que recibe es insuficiente para cubrir las necesidades básicas de su familia y para poder obtener un ingreso extra Maria inició con la venta de cosméticos hace 10 años, ella ha tenido que trabajar mucho para hacer crecer su negocio, pero su gusto por las ventas y el deseo de mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia la han motivado para esforzarse cada día más.

Para poder cubrir las demandas de sus clientes ahora Maria necesita un crédito por la cantidad de $ 925 dólares, mismos que se compromete a regresar en 6 meses. Tú puedes contribuir al desarrollo de este negocio y al bienestar de Maria y su familia, ellos agradecerán mucho tu apoyo.

loans.use: Purchase supplies

loans.name: Guillermina

texts.es:
Business Description

Mrs. Guillermina B. has been in business for fifteen years. She used her own money to start the business. She sells school supplies, gift items, and toys. She runs this business from her home. She also has a dress-making business. She's on the job from seven in the morning until ten at night, every day of the week. Her husband helps her run the business.

Purpose of the Loan

Guillermina would use the loan to by more merchandise, especially gift items in great demand, such as sets of pots and pans, blouses, costume jewelry, and so on.

About the Applicant

Guillermina is fifty. She is married to Pedro. They have three children, including a minor child still in school. Her husband Pedro has a car that he uses to make deliveries, and this additional income helps them make ends meet . Their apartment is made of concrete. They help each other in the business so that they can help the family get ahead and have a better future.

Translated form Spanish by Antonio and Sarah Padial, Kiva Volunteers

Descripción del Negocio

La Sra. Guillermina lleva 15 años dedicada a esta actividad. Ella inicio su negocio con capital propio. Ella vende útiles escolares, artículos de regalo, juguetes. Su negocio esta ubicado en su domicilio. Ella además tiene su taller de costura que también le genera otros ingresos. Su negocio lo atiende desde las 7:00am hasta las 22:00pm todos los días. Su esposo también le ayuda atender el negocio.

Uso del Préstamo

La Sra. Guillermina desea el crédito para comprar más mercadería, sobre todo artículos para regalos como juegos de ollas, blusas, bisutería etc. Ya que estos productos tienen bastante demanda.

Información Personal

La Sra. Guillermina tiene 50 años de edad, esta casada con don Pedro, tienen 3 hijos de los cuales 1 solamente es menor de edad y esta en la escuela. Su esposo Pedro tiene un carrito en el cual realiza fletes que le generan un ingreso adicional para solventar los gastos del hogar. Su vivienda es de un piso de cemento. Ellos juntos se ayudan en el negocio para así sacar adelante a su familia y tener un mejor futuro.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her gift store

loans.name: Mónica Cruz

texts.es:
Monica is 57 years old and lives in San Nicolás de los Garza in the Mexican state of Nuevo León. She's a single mother of three grown-up daughters, two of whom are married and the third is single with three kids who live with Monica. Their mother works to provide for them and afford their education, and Monica, who found it difficult to find employment because of her age, decided to start her own business selling groceries two years ago. Little by little, her supplies and sales have increased.

The desire to help her daughter and her grandchildren motives Monica day to day to keep growing the business. Currently, she is requesting a loan of $475, which she will use to purchase supplies in order to meet her customers' demands and offer them a wider selection. She plans to repay the loan within five months. You can help improve Monica and her family's quality of life. They are very grateful for your confidence and support.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer
